Sentence: In The Color of Water, author James McBride writes both his (McBride) autobiography and a tribute to the life of his (McBride) mother, Ruth McBride
When Ruth became pregnant with Dennis's eighth child, James, Dennis fell ill with lung cancer, and died before James was born
Ruth mourned his (James) death deeply and became desperate to find a means to support herself and her (Ruth) eight children
Ruth's philosophies on race, religion, and work influence him (James) greatly

Ruth remains close with her (Ruth) children, and, later, her (Ruth) grandchildren, holding holiday gatherings that remind James of his (James) household during childhood: chaotic, but delightfully active and stimulating
